title: Link shuts down stricken Woodford fund
text:
London | ASX-listed financial services conglomerate Link Group on Tuesday shut down the stricken flagship fund of British fallen-star stockpicker Neil Woodford, seeking to draw a line under the controversy that has gripped London's investment community.

Link, the fund's administrator, had slammed the gate on the LF Woodford Equity Income Fund (WEIF) in June, at a time when it was worth £3.7 billion ($6.9 billion), as investors began a stampede for the exit following mounting losses and fears about liquidity.

Now Link has written to investors telling them it will not reopen the fund, and will "instead wind it up as soon as practicable ... with a view to returning cash to investors at the earliest opportunity".

Link said the original plan had been to give Woodford Investment Management time to reposition the funds portfolio - shifting investors' capital into more liquid investments, enabling the fund to meet redemption requests - and reopen it in December.

"Whilst progress has been made in relation to repositioning the fund's portfolio, this has unfortunately not been sufficient to allow reasonable certainty as to when the repositioning would be fully achieved and the fund could be reopened," Link wrote to WEIF investors.
description: The ASX-listed group has sacked fallen star stockpicker Neil Woodford from his own flagship fund, which used to be worth $6.9 billion.
